name: 2,4,6-trimethylbenzyl alcohol
Reason: 2,4,6-trimethylbenzyl alcohol has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The presence of three methyl groups (two attached to the benzene ring and one attached to the alcohol group) increases the molecular weight and rigidity of the structure, estimated at around +20 °C for each methyl group. The benzene ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its planarity and rigidity, estimated at around +20 °C. The alcohol group introduces a hydroxyl functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point by approximately +10 °C.
